<Summary source="https://foxnews.com/live-news/nancy-guthrie-disappearance-arizona-feb-17-live-updates">
# Summary of Article: "Nancy Guthrie latest: Genealogy testing underway after FBI confirms no CODIS hit on DNA"

**Source:** Fox News  
**Date:** February 17, 2026  
**Author:** Greg Wehner

## Key Facts and Developments:

### DNA Testing and Investigative Genetic Genealogy (IGG)
- **FBI confirmed** that investigative genetic genealogy (IGG) is being used to test DNA found on a glove discovered two miles from Nancy Guthrie's home and other DNA samples found inside her house
- **No CODIS hits:** The unknown male DNA profile on the glove and DNA found in Guthrie's home produced no matches in the CODIS database
- **IGG already underway:** An FBI official confirmed that investigative genetic genealogy is already being conducted in the investigation
- **Expert opinion:** Ce Ce Moore, chief genetic genealogist at Parabon Nano Labs, stated she has "full confidence that investigative genetic genealogy will be able to identify that DNA contributor" and that "it is just a matter of time now until they discover who that DNA belongs to"

### Investigation Status
- **Next phase:** Pima County Sheriff Chris Nanos said investigators are debriefing recent forensic findings and prioritizing additional lab work, including separating merged DNA samples recovered inside Guthrie's residence
- **Video evidence:** Authorities still do not have video from Guthrie's other cameras; the video is currently "in the hands of Google"
- **Photo analysis:** Sheriff Nanos told NBC he has seen a photo that could show the suspect wearing a ring, but investigators will analyze the image before drawing conclusions

### Search Technology and Methods
- **Blue Fly® technology:** Parsons Corporation confirmed it deployed specialized Bluetooth and Wi-Fi detection technology during the search, beginning in early February. The system "provides first responders with a heat map to identify signals within a search area" and was used via helicopter, ground vehicles, and on foot
- **K-9 searches:** U.S. Border Patrol's elite BORSTAR search and rescue team used a bright blue shirt found at Guthrie's home for K-9 scent searches. The team was called to the property twice

### Other Details
- **Adult Protective Services:** Sheriff Nanos clarified that after a neighbor called APS, an investigator was sent to Guthrie's home the day she was reported missing
- **Mexico border:** Sheriff Nanos stated there is no evidence Nancy Guthrie was taken across the border into Mexico, though investigators are aware of the region's proximity
- **Ongoing activity:** Two men wearing badges were seen entering a home next door to Guthrie's residence; two men were also seen walking the grounds of Guthrie's property on Tuesday

**Context:** Nancy Guthrie is an 84-year-old missing woman whose case is being investigated by the Pima County Sheriff's Department and FBI.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.latimes.com/world-nation/story/2026-02-17/nancy-guthrie-key-evidence">
# Summary of Los Angeles Times Article (February 17, 2026)

## Key Facts and Timeline:

- **Nancy Guthrie, 84 years old**, was kidnapped from her Tucson home
- **Kidnapping occurred**: February 1, 2026 at approximately 1:47 a.m.
- **Article date**: February 17, 2026 (updated 10:58 AM PT)
- **Time elapsed since kidnapping**: More than three weeks at time of article
- Guthrie was discovered missing after failing to show up at a friend's house to watch a church service
- She was taken without her heart medication; unclear how long she can survive without it

## Evidence and Investigation Details:

**Video footage:**
- Grainy black-and-white surveillance video shows a masked individual at Guthrie's front door at 1:47 a.m. on Feb. 1
- Person wore: balaclava, gloves, backpack, and had a visible holstered gun at front of body
- Individual noticed the camera and attempted to cover the lens, eventually using yard greenery
- Video became public one week before this article (approximately Feb. 10, 2026)

**DNA Evidence:**
- DNA found on a glove discovered 2 miles from Guthrie's home matched gloves worn by masked person in video (announced Sunday, Feb. 15)
- As of Tuesday (Feb. 17), DNA did not match anything in CODIS (national DNA database)
- Additional DNA evidence found at Guthrie's home is being tested; results pending

**Other clues:**
- Investigators believe clothing, backpack, and face mask may have been purchased at Walmart
- Working with Walmart management to identify purchaser
- Ransom notes were sent to news outlets a day after Guthrie disappeared
- Authorities treated ransom notes as legitimate; sources told The Times the note felt credible because it included non-public details about damaged property and placement of an accessory in the home
- However, authorities have no proof the ransom note author actually has Guthrie

**Suspects:**
- Two people were detained for questioning but later released
- No current suspect identified

## Statements from Authorities:

**Chris Nanos, Pima County Sheriff** (to Daily Mail):
- "I believe somebody out there knows who this is"
- "I believe somebody out there can look at that video and go, I know exactly who that is"
- Compared case to Unabomber investigation, where Theodore Kaczynski was identified after his brother recognized similarities in the manifesto

**FBI Director Kash Patel** (on X, last week):
- Law enforcement worked for days to recover images/video that may have been "lost, corrupted, or inaccessible due to a variety of factors — including the removal of recording devices"

## Expert Opinions:

**Mary Ellen O'Toole, Professor at George Mason University:**
- "Someone is going to recognize this individual. They're going to recognize the clothes, they'll recognize the gait and how he carries himself. I think that is going to be significant"

**Andrew Black, University of Hawaii Police Chief:**
- "He or she is not going to be dressed exactly as they were here, but they're going to have used some of these articles of clothing in daily life"

## Family Response:

**Savannah Guthrie** ("Today" show co-host, issued statement Sunday on Instagram):
- Pleaded with kidnappers: "it's never too late, and you're not lost or alone, and it is never too late to do the right thing"
- "We are here and we believe, and we believe in the essential goodness of every human being, and it's never too late"
- Family has expressed concern about Nancy's health due to missing medication

## Investigation Status:

- No proof of life provided for Nancy Guthrie
- Case has "captivated the nation" but there have been "relatively few leads"
- Authorities believe video holds the key to solving the case and are relying on tips from the public
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://abc7news.com/live-updates/nancy-guthrie-live-updates/18612498/">
# Summary of Article: Nancy Guthrie live updates: Glove DNA doesn't match anyone in national database, sheriff says

**Source:** ABC7 San Francisco  
**Date:** February 17, 2026

## Key Facts and Timeline:

**Background:**
- Nancy Guthrie, 84-year-old mother of "Today" host Savannah Guthrie, was abducted from her home near Tucson, Arizona on Sunday, February 1, 2026
- Investigators believe she was abducted in her sleep early on Feb. 1

**Timeline of Events (Feb. 1):**
- 1:47 a.m.: Nancy Guthrie's doorbell camera disconnected
- 2:12 a.m.: Camera software detected a person, but no video is available
- 11:56 a.m.: Relatives discovered she was missing
- 12:03 p.m.: Family called 911

**Investigation Details:**
- FBI released photos and videos of an armed, masked person in front of her home, appearing to tamper with a security camera
- Authorities have received over 30,000 tips, according to Sheriff Chris Nanos
- Two men who were briefly detained are not suspects
- Motive remains unknown; investigators don't know if it was a kidnapping or burglary gone wrong

**DNA Evidence:**
- A glove was found about 2 miles from Nancy Guthrie's house during a roadside search
- DNA from this glove was run through the national CODIS database (containing roughly 22 million samples) with no match
- This glove DNA also did not match DNA found at Guthrie's property
- DNA found at the property is still being analyzed and requires further testing
- The glove DNA remains at a private lab in Florida (sent Feb. 12) undergoing quality control tests before FBI runs it through CODIS in the "near future"

**Family Status:**
- Sheriff Chris Nanos stated Monday that all Guthrie family members, including siblings and spouses, are "cleared" as suspects
- Family described as "cooperative and gracious" and "victims in this case"

**Current Status:**
- When asked if there's evidence Nancy Guthrie is alive, Sheriff Nanos said there's been no evidence that she is not alive
- Anyone with information is urged to call 911 or Pima County Sheriff's Department at 520-351-4900
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://news.azpm.org/s/102743-no-dna-match-in-nancy-guthrie-case/">
# Summary of Article: "No DNA match in Nancy Guthrie case"

**Source:** News.azpm  
**Date:** February 17, 2026, 4:51 p.m.  
**Author:** Katya Mendoza

## Key Facts and Developments:

**DNA Evidence:**
- DNA from gloves found two miles from Nancy Guthrie's home did not match any entries in a national DNA database
- The glove DNA also did not match DNA found at the property
- Additional DNA evidence obtained from the property is still being tested

**Investigation Status (as of Day 17 of disappearance):**
- Investigators are working with experts and the manufacturer to locate Guthrie's pacemaker (she is 84 years old)
- Working with Walmart management to identify the buyer of an Ozark Trail backpack worn by the armed suspect
- Canvassing local gun shops to determine if the suspect is familiar to anyone
- Evidence from two recent search warrants is still being processed
- Individuals who were questioned have been released; no arrests have been made
- Family members have been ruled out as suspects

**Suspect Description:**
- Seen in surveillance footage approaching Guthrie's front door
- Armed
- Between 5 feet, 9-10 inches tall with an average build

**Background:**
- Nancy Guthrie was taken from her Catalina Foothills home on Sunday, February 1, reportedly against her will
- She is the mother of "Today" show host Savannah Guthrie
- FBI announced a $100,000 reward for information leading to her return and the arrest/conviction of those responsible
- Over the weekend, Savannah Guthrie addressed potential abductors on social media, saying "it's never too late...to do the right thing"
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://nypost.com/2026/02/16/us-news/trump-tells-the-post-he-wants-death-penalty-for-nancy-guthrie-kidnappers-if-she-isnt-returned-alive/">
# Summary of Article: "Trump threatens kidnappers with death penalty if Nancy Guthrie isn't returned alive in call with The Post"

**Source:** New York Post  
**Date:** February 16, 2026  
**Author:** Steven Nelson

## Key Facts and Statistics:

- Nancy Guthrie, 84-year-old mother of NBC "Today" show host Savannah Guthrie, was abducted from her home outside Tucson on February 1, 2026
- President Trump called Savannah Guthrie on February 4 to offer federal assistance
- The FBI recovered images and video last week showing a masked man at the suburban home's front door
- Authorities are conducting flights above the desert region with high-tech Bluetooth devices attempting to locate a signal from Nancy Guthrie's pacemaker
- Arizona currently has 109 inmates on death row, many there for decades
- Arizona has carried out just two executions since 2022, partly due to a nearly two-year pause by the Democrat-led state government that was lifted in late 2024
- Former President Biden commuted the sentences of 37 of 40 men on federal death row (excluding Tsarnaev, Bowers, and Roof)

## Statements from Named Sources:

**President Trump (in phone interview with The Post on Monday, February 16, 2026):**
- Said kidnappers must release Nancy Guthrie unharmed or face the "most severe" federal penalties
- Would want the Justice Department to seek the death penalty if Nancy Guthrie is killed
- Confirmed abductors would face "very, very severe — the most severe" federal consequences if she is found dead
- When asked if that meant the death penalty, answered: "The most, yeah — that's true"

## Additional Context:

- Authorities believe Nancy Guthrie may still be alive
- Federal charges are common in high-profile cases, particularly with interstate components or federal statute violations
- Trump officials plan to move remaining federal death row inmates to a federal supermax prison
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.kvoa.com/video/the-latest-in-the-disappearance-of-nancy-guthrie/video_9e30d866-de6c-5ff2-97c7-e921ac3ce9d5.html">

1. **Subject:** Nancy Guthrie, 84-year-old mother of TODAY show co-host Savannah Guthrie, is missing

2. **Timeline:** The search is in its third week (as of February 17, 2026)

3. **Investigation Status:** 
   - Investigators are expanding their search for DNA
   - Technology is being used to help locate Nancy's pacemaker

The article appears to be brief and provides limited detail beyond these basic facts about the ongoing search. No specific information about the circumstances of the disappearance, location, or other investigative details are included in the extracted content.

**Nancy Guthrie Update today: No DNA matches on suspected glove, fourth ransom note reaches TMZ | Today News**
Nancy Guthrie, the 84-year-old mother of Savannah Guthrie, co-anchor of NBC's 'Today' show, has been missing since February 1, 2026. As of February 18, 2026, a fourth ransom note was received by TMZ from an individual claiming to have information about her whereabouts, demanding confidential payment in bitcoin. The initial ransom note, also demanding millions in bitcoin, had a deadline that passed without payment. TMZ received additional messages from the same individual, who warned that cooperation would cease if payment was not made. According to the article, no DNA matches were found on a suspected glove linked to the case. The article cites 'mint' as the source.

**'Today' Hosts Pray for Savannah Guthrie's Family Live On-Air**
On the February 17, 2026, episode of NBC's 'Today,' hosts Hoda Kotb, Craig Melvin, and Carson Daly invited the new Archbishop of New York, Ronald Hicks, to discuss his role and offer spiritual support during the ongoing investigation into the disappearance of Nancy, last seen in Tucson, Arizona, on January 31, 2026. Hicks expressed heartfelt support, stating he and a community of people are praying for Nancy, her mother, and the entire family. Melvin requested a brief prayer, which Hicks delivered, asking for God’s light, grace, mercy, and goodness to bring hope, peace, and resolution to the situation. The hosts appeared emotional during the moment. As of the report, the investigation has entered its third week, with no persons of interest named and a $100,000 reward offered for information. Alleged ransom notes demanding millions have not been confirmed as authentic. Savannah Guthrie and her siblings, Annie and Camron, have released multiple social media plea videos seeking their mother’s safe return and proof of life, and have stated they are willing to pay. Officials have ruled out Savannah and her family—including her and her siblings’ spouses—as suspects. A glove found near Nancy’s home contained male DNA, but authorities have not confirmed whether it matches the suspect’s gloves in security footage. On February 12, the hosts had previously discussed the case with psychotherapist Niro Feliciano, who advised that 'love wins, and love will always win,' drawing inspiration from the Sandy Hook community’s resilience 13 years after the tragedy.

**Savannah Guthrie posts new video: "It is never too late to do the right thing" - KTSA**
Nancy Guthrie, 84, has been missing since February 1, 2026, with her last sighting on January 31, 2026, during dinner with her daughter Annie Guthrie and son-in-law. Authorities believe she was abducted in the middle of the night. The FBI released video and images from a Google Nest camera showing a man with an average build, approximately 5 feet 9 inches to 5 feet 10 inches tall, wearing a ski mask, gloves, and a black 25-liter Ozark Trail Hiker Pack backpack, which is sold exclusively at Walmart. Law enforcement reviewed footage from a Walmart location in Tucson, though Walmart corporate declined to comment. A black glove found near Guthrie’s home matches the gloves in the video and contains DNA evidence being tested; preliminary results were received on Saturday, with confirmation pending before entering the unknown male profile into the FBI’s CODIS database, a process that typically takes 24 hours. The Guthrie family has released multiple videos urging the abductor to return Nancy, emphasizing that 'it is never too late to do the right thing,' and expressing belief in the essential goodness of every human being. Authorities are investigating a ransom note demanding payment in bitcoin, initially sent to CBS News affiliate KOLD-TV, which the family addressed in a video while requesting proof of life. At least two homes have been searched, including one less than two miles from Guthrie’s residence, searched Friday evening by multiple agencies including the Pima County Sheriff SWAT team. Pima County Sheriff Chris Nanos confirmed a search warrant was issued based on a lead, with no arrest made. A person of interest was apprehended during a traffic stop and later released, and another individual detained during a separate traffic stop south of Tucson was also released. No suspect has been officially named.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 16, 2026 11:10 AM
Source:[KTSA 550 AM](https://www.ktsa.com/savannah-guthrie-posts-new-video-it-is-never-too-late-to-do-the-right-thing/)

**Digital forensics could break Nancy Guthrie case as new video gives Sheriff hope: Here's why**
The search for 84-year-old Nancy Guthrie, who was abducted from her $1 million home outside Tucson, Arizona, on February 1, 2026, entered its third week on February 16, 2026. Pima County Sheriff Chris Nanos expressed hope that digital forensics could uncover new evidence, particularly through efforts by Google specialists working on cloud-based video systems from security cameras at Guthrie’s residence. Initially, Google reported no data, but stated they would attempt to 'scratch'—a delicate process akin to removing eight layers of paint to reach deeper data, with the goal of accessing the sixth or seventh layer without damaging existing information. Nanos emphasized that his officers processed the scene for nearly 20 hours, collected all evidence, and handed it over to the FBI. Over 400 personnel from the Pima County Sheriff's Department, the FBI, and other Arizona law enforcement agencies are actively involved in the investigation.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 16, 2026 10:03 AM

**Guthrie pleads for mother's release as FBI analyses glove**
Savannah Guthrie, co-anchor of NBC's 'Today' show, has renewed her plea for the safe return of her 84-year-old mother, Nancy Guthrie, who has been missing since January 31, 2026, after being last seen at her home near Tucson, Arizona. Authorities reported her missing the following day. The FBI has obtained a DNA sample from a glove found near her residence, which appears to match the gloves worn by a masked man captured on doorbell camera footage attempting to disable her home’s security system before her abduction. Preliminary results from a private Florida lab were received on Saturday, and the FBI is conducting a national CODIS database search, with a 'hit' potentially confirmed within 24 hours. The glove is one of about 16 collected from a roadside field approximately 3km from her home; most were discarded by searchers, but this one is distinct and matches the suspect’s attire. Pima County Sheriff Chris Nanos stated the suspect, seen wearing a gun holster and an over-stuffed backpack, is the primary person of interest and that Nancy, who has limited mobility, pacemaker, and frail health, was likely taken against her will. Traces of Nancy’s blood were found on her front porch, confirmed by DNA testing. Two purported ransom notes were delivered to media outlets, but no direct contact has been made with the family or authorities. Law enforcement has not confirmed any proof of life or death. Acting on a federal court warrant, deputies and FBI agents searched a residence less than 3km from Nancy’s home on Friday night. Savannah Guthrie, her brother Camron Guthrie, and sister Annie Guthrie have released multiple video appeals, expressing hope, willingness to meet ransom demands, and belief in humanity. The FBI confirmed that DNA not belonging to Nancy or her family members was also found on her property, but no official results have been released for those samples.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 16, 2026 06:44 AM
Source:[RTE.ie](https://www.rte.ie/news/2026/0216/1558675-savannah-guthrie/)

**This week on "Sunday Morning" (Feb. 15)**
CBS News Sunday Morning, hosted by Jane Pauley, aired on February 15, 2026, featuring a cover story on Gisèle Pelicot, who became a public figure in a high-profile mass rape trial in France where her husband was convicted of drugging her and orchestrating the abuse by dozens of men. In her first interview, Pelicot discusses her memoir, 'A Hymn to Life: Shame Has to Change Sides,' her decision to testify publicly, and her personal transformation. The segment also includes a historical look at February 15, highlighting General George Washington’s crossing of the Delaware River on Christmas 1776, examined through the lens of climate change by environmental correspondent David Schechter. Additional segments cover the disappearance of Nancy Guthrie, actor Jacob Elordi’s Oscar nomination for 'Frankenstein' and his remake of 'Wuthering Heights,' a tribute to notable figures who passed away, a culinary exploration of Fettuccine Alfredo in Rome, a profile of singer Paul Anka at 84 discussing his seven-decade career, and a conversation with sports commentator Stephen A. Smith about his political commentary and potential future in debates. The episode also includes a retrospective on school shooting victims’ bedrooms, a tribute by Steve Hartman and Lou Bopp, and a YouTube compilation of classic Winter Olympics stories. The show airs on CBS at 9:00 a.m. ET and streams on the CBS News app at 11:00 a.m. ET, with full episodes available on CBSNews.com, CBS.com, and Paramount+.

**NBC Breaks Into Olympics to Cover Latest On Nancy Guthrie**
On February 11, 2026, NBC News broke into its live coverage of the 2026 Winter Olympics to deliver a 10-minute special report on the abduction of Nancy Guthrie, the 84-year-old mother of Today show host Savannah Guthrie. Anchor Hallie Jackson announced that a man had been detained by law enforcement for questioning in connection with her disappearance, according to a source familiar with the matter. ABC and CBS also interrupted regular programming to report the same development, with David Muir anchoring for ABC and Jessi Mitchell for CBS. Cable networks responded with extensive coverage: Fox News preempted Gutfeld! for a live special anchored by Trace Gallagher from Arizona, promising to remain on air through the night. CNN’s Jake Tapper took over live coverage from Tucson, while MS NOW’s Lawrence O’Donnell dedicated his entire A-Block to the case before shifting to another major breaking story—the U.S. Department of Justice’s failed attempt to indict six Democratic members of Congress for urging troops to disregard illegal orders. The incident marked a rare moment when major broadcast and cable networks prioritized a high-profile abduction case over a major international sporting event.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 11, 2026 04:17 AM
Source:[Mediaite](https://www.mediaite.com/media/nbc-breaks-into-olympics-coverage-as-networks-go-wall-to-wall-on-new-developments-in-nancy-guthrie-case/)

**BREAKING: Person Detained for Questioning in Connection With Nancy Guthrie's Abduction**
A person has been detained for questioning in connection with the abduction of Nancy Guthrie, according to multiple reports released late Tuesday, February 11, 2026. The individual was apprehended by the Pima County Sheriff's Department with assistance from the FBI in the Tucson area. FBI Director Kash Patel confirmed to Fox News host Sean Hannity prior to the reports that there are now persons of interest in the case.
